text: Two possible outcomes of executing a txn: » Commit after completing all its actions. » Abort (or be aborted by the DBMS) after executing some actions. DBMS guarantees that txns are atomic. » From user’s point of view: txn always either executes all its actions, or executes no actions at all. !l > ' £2CMU-D8 - Ÿ' C4 A - \ _.’-' is ) i — P e 4 D PI % 26:40/1:23:07 - ATOMICITY OF TRANSACTIONS > -—.Œ Ÿ # O . 16 - Concurrency Control Theory (CMU Databases Systems / Fall 2019)
